generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

Recall,

Integration by parts is given by the formula, \(\displaystyle \int udv=uv-\int vdu \)

Let \(u={@u@}\) and \(dv={@dv@}\,dx\)

Then, \(du={@du@}\,dx\) and \(v={@v@}\).

\(\displaystyle \int {@quest_expr@}\,dx={@uv_1@}-\displaystyle \int {@vdu_1@}\,dx \,\,\,\,(1)\)

Hence applying integration by parts for the second time to \((1)\)

\(u={@u_2@} \Rightarrow du={@du_2@}\,dx\) and \(dv={@dv_2@}\,dx\), then \(v={@v_2@}\)

\(\displaystyle \int {@u_2@}{@dv_2@}\,dx={@u2_v2@}-\int {@v_du_2@}\,dx\)

But \(\displaystyle \int {@quest_expr@}\,dx={@uv_1@}-\displaystyle \int {@vdu_1@}\,dx={@uv_1@}+{@u2_v2@}-\int {@v_du_2@}\,dx\)

By collecting like terms, you obtain

\( \displaystyle \int {@quest_expr@}\,dx+\int {@v_du_2@}\,dx={@u2_v2@}+{@uv_1@}\)

\(\displaystyle \int {@quest_expr@}\,dx= {@ta1@}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: You answer is partially correct because you forgot the constant of integration
